question.questionA: Epicalyx with two to three lobes.
question.questionB: Epicalyx with six to nine lobes.

question.questionA: Lobes of epicalyx fused at base.
question.questionB: Lobes of epicalyx free at base.

question.questionA: Flowers in axillary clusters of two or more.
question.questionB: Flowers axillary, solitary or rarely in pairs.

question.questionA: Annuals to perennials with thick woody stems up to 3 m; leaves to 20 cm, often folded fan-wise; flowers 3-4 cm, petals rosy purple, purple veined; epicalyx longer than calyx, elongating in fruit.
question.questionB: Annuals or biennials 50-150 cm; petals violet, 1-2 cm; epicalyx shorter than calyx.

question.questionA: Annuals or perennials with herbaceous stems.
question.questionB: Shrubs or perennials with a woody base.

question.questionA: Plants not covered with bristly hairs; leaves regularly dentate, upper simple, lower hastate.
question.questionB: Plants  covered with bristly hairs;  leaves  irregularly dentate, maple-shaped.

question.questionA: Flowers pale pink or purple, pedicels as long as subtending petiole.
Petals  twice  to  four  times  the  length of  the  calyx, deeply notched; epicalyx shorter than sepals.
question.questionB: Petals less than twice the length of the calyx.
